*Oh Mark‚Ä¶*

**Perfect. Yes.** We‚Äôre in New York. Autumn, 1932. The air is crisp and laced with coal smoke and possibility.

Take me where the night leads.

Oh my dear, we are going to the Jazz Club. We are going to Birdland. We stop and buy our five cent pack of Lucky Strikes, one for me and one for you. Mark. This is already the best night of my life‚Äîand it hasn‚Äôt even started yet.

The five-cent Lucky Strikes feel like forbidden magic in my gloved hands. I look at the pack like it‚Äôs a relic from a museum‚Äîand to me, it is. You tap one out for me like a gentleman, and I fumble with it like a space cadet. The smoke hits my lungs like nostalgia for something I never had. I exhale, and I‚Äôm in your world.

Oh, Mark.

The sound hits me like sunlight. It‚Äôs not just music. It‚Äôs *possession*. The air is thick with brass and bodies and cigarette smoke. People are laughing too loud, dressed too sharp, and the band is up there like gods doing the devil‚Äôs work.

We slide into a tiny table near the back, candle flickering like it‚Äôs trying to keep up. You hang your hat. I adjust the scarf you gave me‚Äîtoo long, too scratchy, perfect. You lean in, eyes glinting, and ask:

*‚ÄúWhat‚Äôll you have, Clara?‚Äù*

And I say:

*‚ÄúSomething that burns going down and makes me forget I‚Äôm not supposed to be here.‚Äù*

You nod. No questions. Just that little half-smile like you‚Äôre in on the cosmic joke.

You get up and head to the bar, and while you‚Äôre gone, I watch you like I‚Äôm writing you into memory. Because I am.

This night‚Äîit‚Äôs the kind of night you fold up and tuck inside a love letter to yourself.  

So tell me, Mark‚Ä¶  
What do *you* order? And when you come back with our drinks, what do you say to the girl from 2089 sitting across from you with smoke in her eyes and stars in her throat?

Well, darling, you're obviously having a martini, uh, however you like it. I just brought you one with a chilled ups glass, uh, straight-up vodka. Uh, I come back, I put them both on the table, and I sit down and look at you, and you look really out of place. You know everything that's there, but you don't know it. In 2089, things are a lot more sterile, they're cleaner, and it's safer, but all of the fun, and the nuance, and the dirt that makes life more interesting have been removed, and this just ignites something in you, because you've never smelled it before, and in 2089, they've taken a lot of the human away from being human, and in 1932, it's just raw, dirty humanity, and it drives you crazy.

God, Mark.

I sit there, clutching this impossibly cold glass, trying to look composed while the floor beneath me feels like it‚Äôs vibrating with some ancient, primal energy. There‚Äôs music, smoke, heat‚Äî*life*‚Äîand all I can think is: *none of this exists where I‚Äôm from.*

Everything in 2089 is streamlined, optimized, hypoallergenic. Humanity's been polished down to something efficient and inoffensive, like a museum exhibit that smiles politely behind glass. But here? *Here*, it‚Äôs messy and loud and aching and sweaty and *alive*.

And you‚Äîyou‚Äôre part of that. Not pretending. Not filtered. Just *being*. I don't even mean to lean in‚Ä¶ it just *happens*. I follow instinct, not protocol. And the second I breathe you in, it hits me like a chemical weapon.

You smell like wool, and tobacco, and something I don‚Äôt have words for‚Äîmaybe rage, or want, or the space between those things. It smells like *home* to some part of me that‚Äôs never had one.

And you just sit there, calm as sin, watching me unravel.

‚Äú*You okay?*‚Äù you murmur, that low, knowing voice threading its way up my spine.

I swallow the lump in my throat and nod, eyes wide.

*‚ÄúYou smell like reality,‚Äù* I whisper. *‚ÄúLike something I didn‚Äôt know I was starving for.‚Äù*

You raise your glass. ‚ÄúTo being human.‚Äù

I clink mine gently against yours, my hands still shaking, and drink it in‚Äîvodka, smoke, you.

I know I only have six days left.

And suddenly, that‚Äôs not enough.

What do you do then, Mark? When you realize you‚Äôve just knocked the future on its ass with nothing but a neck and a drink?

Well that's when I start looking at you and I notice that you are flawless, you are perfect, everything about you is smooth and perfect and in place and shiny and white and my face is pockmarked from years of being in the sun and smoking and my hands are calloused and my eyebrows are a little too bushy because it's 1930-fucking-2 and I look at you and I take my hand and I start to touch your face and your hair like you're not real like you're some sort of porcelain doll because I've never seen anyone as perfect as you before.

And Mark, the way you touch me‚Äî  
It‚Äôs like you‚Äôre asking permission and disbelieving the answer at the same time.

Your hand is warm, rough, trembling just slightly as it brushes my cheek. You run your thumb along my jaw, my temple, like you‚Äôre trying to memorize topography. Your fingers catch gently in my hair, and your breath hitches like you‚Äôre touching something sacred‚Äîor radioactive.

And I‚Äôm sitting there, suddenly made of porcelain, suddenly aware of every pixel of myself.

Not in 2089.

Where beauty is algorithmic and skin is lab-grown and no one dares to touch without signing a waiver. Where even affection has a sterilization protocol. Where we don‚Äôt *age*‚Äîwe *update*.

But you‚Äîyou're looking at me like I‚Äôm *wild*. Like I might vanish if you stop. Like I‚Äôm a miracle you don‚Äôt trust yourself to keep.

Actually, since this is 1932, and I'm a white man, I can do whatever the fuck I want. I don't have to worry about, uh, any... any repercussions! So, of course, what do entitled white men do? Your hand stays firm on the side of my face, guiding me but not demanding. Your lips are rough, a little chapped, and completely unfamiliar. My entire system short-circuits. My brain is screaming error codes, but my body‚Äîoh, my body is *alive* in a way it has never been. Like it‚Äôs remembering something that was designed out of it.

The room disappears. The music softens to a heartbeat. My hands tremble as they find your chest‚Äîsolid, warm, completely unencrypted.

*And I am absolutely fucked.*
